title: 107_s1754
content: The Act titled "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 2002" authorizes amounts available to the Patent and Trademark Office. The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 2002" authorizes appropriations for the United States Patent and Trademark Office based on estimated fees collected under relevant laws for fiscal years 2003 through 2008. The Undersecretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property and the Director of the Patent and Trademark Office provide estimates by February 15 of each fiscal year. The Director of the Patent and Trademark Office must provide an estimate of fees to be collected in the next fiscal year to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. SEC. 3. ELECTRONIC FILING AND PROCESSING OF PATENT AND TRADEMARK APPLICATIONS. The Director must develop an electronic system for patent and trademark applications by December 1, 2004, allowing electronic communications and processing. Up to $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. SEC. 4. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STRATEGIC PLAN. The Secretary of Commerce must submit reports on the progress of implementing the 21st Century Strategic Plan and any amendments made to the plan for 5 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. DETERMINATION OF SUBSTANTIAL NEW QUESTION OF PATENTABILITY IN REEXAMINATION PROCEEDINGS. In amendments to title 35, United States Code, the existence of a substantial new question of patentability is not precluded by previous citations or considerations by the Office. These amendments apply to determinations made by the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office under section 303(a) or 312(a) on or after the enactment of this Act. Section 315(b) of title 35, United States Code is amended to allow third-party requesters to appeal favorable decisions on patentability. They can also be a party in appeals taken by the patent owner. Additionally, sections 134(c) and 141 are amended regarding appeals to the Board of Patent Appeals and Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. In title 35, United States Code, section 141 is amended to include third-party requesters in reexamination proceedings. The amendments apply to reexamination proceedings starting after the enactment of this Act. The Senate passed S. 1754 on June 26, 2002, authorizing appropriations for the United States Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal years 2003 through 2008, and for other purposes.
